message.content:
Sure! Here's a regex expression that should match your desired code:
```
\b(?<code>[\w]{3})\b
```
Here's how it works:

* `\b` matches a word boundary, ensuring that the code is not preceded or followed by any other characters.
* `(?<code>[\w]{3})` is a named capture group that matches exactly three characters (letters, digits, or underscores) that are not word characters (i.e., they are not whitespace or punctuation). The `{3}` indicates that we want exactly three of these characters.
* `\b` again matches a word boundary, ensuring that the code is not part of a larger word.

Here's an example of how this regex expression might match your desired code in the given filename:
```
57-1Jn.usfm
```
In this example, the regex expression would match the code "1Jn" and return it as a captured group named "code".

Note that this regex expression will only match filenames with the exact format you specified (i.e., "57-[3 character code].usfm"). If you need to match a wider range of filenames, you may need to adjust the expression accordingly.
